Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: CDE seminar featured excellent speakers and relevant topics, and I enjoyed learning more about research related to chronic diseases from researchers at Yale and beyond.

Strength: The course provides an overview to some public health problems.
Weakness: Some topics are not interesting to me.
Really excellent speakers in all field

The scheduling was very problematic. Practically none in the fall, but then all of them were this semester - almost every week. It got too hectic. Perhaps fewer, but longer seminars would be better to afford time for discussion.

Strengths - speakers were always engaging
Weaknesses - potentially offering individuals in areas other than research would be interesting and useful
Good to hear different study projects.
Enjoyed hearing from CDE practitioners, but did feel like the number of seminars was a little high.
I really enjoyed the range of topics covered during this seminar series.

Very interesting talks this semester! I like the seminar much more than the one in the fall (at least this year!). I appreciate that there was wider range of topics related to chronic disease prevention and management, from social determinants of health, to biological determinants of health, to intervention research.

I really think having a more flexible schedule would be ideal (eg. have the seminar every week, and then require people to go to 70% of them). Sometimes it was really tricky to balance it with other workload requirements!
The course is great!  The lectures are all fantastic and I am confident that the speakers invited will continue to be fabulous as the years go on.
This class is catered towards people who are only interested in pursuing research. I would really like to see some speakers that are in different fields.
The food choices weren't very good
Dr. Hawley organized a great seminar series and always effectively communicated information related to the seminars.

Strength: Dr. Hawley is an excellent instructor.
Weakness: This lecture is a seminar, and some topics may not be interesting to students.
Thanks to Porfessor Hawley's well arrangement, we have spent time with the awesome speakers discussing many interesting topics.
She's great! Open to student recommendations for seminar requests.
Dr. Hawley and the other CDE faculty and staff did a fantastic job organizing these talks.
Professor Hawley did a great job organizing the seminar series, and hopefully will continue to lead the way in organizing them in the future.
Would recommend (although it is required for CDE students). Research presentations were stimulating and interesting

A seminar wherein you learn about various public health problems and are given the opportunity to ask questions regarding current research.

I would recommend this course in order for students to have a grasp on the current state of public health work.

CDE seminars are mandatory for first year students, but they are a nice break from classwork and provide the opportunity to learn about relevant research and connect with researchers across the country.
This course is a mandatory course for 1st-year students. It has nothing to do with recommendations.
This is a seminar required by first year students.
You have to take it. Try to enjoy the talks; some fascinating people.
general seminar on a variety of CDE topics. would recommend if people were interested in random subjects, but not for an organized review of CDE topics.
I would, and I believe that, if space permits, second years should be encouraged or required to attend next year.
Great! I would recommend all students outside of CDE to drop by.
The seminars are a wonderful way to learn about current topics in chronic disease epidemiology, and I would highly recommended them to those outside of the department as well.
